supporting.text: French is the official language of France, a European country, and is widely spoken there.

attacks.text: French is the official language of France, a European country, and is widely spoken there.
Not all European countries have French as an official language, such as Germany or Italy.
Many Europeans speak languages other than French as their primary language.
Even in France, regional languages like Breton or Occitan are spoken, not just French.
English is more commonly spoken as a second language across Europe than French.

supporting.text: French is one of the official languages of the European Union, indicating its prominence in Europe.

attacks.text: French is one of the official languages of the European Union, indicating its prominence in Europe.
Many European countries do not have French as an official or widely spoken language, such as Germany or Poland.
The European Union has 24 official languages, showing linguistic diversity rather than French dominance.
Even in countries where French is spoken, it is often a secondary language, not the primary one.
The prominence of French in the EU does not imply widespread fluency among all Europeans.
Regional languages and dialects are more commonly used in daily communication than French in many parts of Europe.

supporting.text: Many European countries, such as Belgium, Switzerland, and Luxembourg, have significant French-speaking populations.

attacks.text: Many European countries, such as Belgium, Switzerland, and Luxembourg, have significant French-speaking populations.
Not all regions in these countries speak French; some primarily speak other languages like German or Dutch.
Many European countries, such as Germany, Italy, and Spain, have minimal or no French-speaking populations.
Even in multilingual countries like Belgium, French is not universally spoken across all regions.
National language policies in countries like Germany and Spain prioritize their native languages over French.

supporting.text: Not all Europeans speak French; many countries like Germany, Italy, and Spain have their own dominant languages.

attacks.text: Not all Europeans speak French; many countries like Germany, Italy, and Spain have their own dominant languages.
French is widely taught as a second language in many European schools, increasing its prevalence.
The European Union promotes multilingualism, but French remains one of its official working languages, suggesting its importance.
Despite being taught, fluency in French is not universal, and many Europeans only have basic knowledge.
Even if French is an official EU language, it doesn't mean all Europeans speak it fluently or at all.
Surveys show that a significant portion of Europeans cannot hold a conversation in French.

supporting.text: In Eastern Europe, languages like Russian, Polish, and Hungarian are more commonly spoken than French.

attacks.text: In Eastern Europe, languages like Russian, Polish, and Hungarian are more commonly spoken than French.
French is widely taught as a second language in many Eastern European schools, increasing its prevalence.
The presence of minority French-speaking communities in Eastern Europe contradicts the claim that French is not spoken there.
Despite being taught, French is rarely used in daily communication compared to local languages in Eastern Europe.
Minority communities do not significantly impact the overall language statistics of a region.
Surveys show that even among those who learn French, fluency and usage rates remain low in Eastern Europe.

supporting.text: English is more widely spoken as a second language across Europe than French.

attacks.text: English is more widely spoken as a second language across Europe than French.
French is still the official language in multiple European countries, such as France and Belgium.
Many Europeans learn French as their first foreign language in school.
Even in countries where French is an official language, not all citizens speak it fluently.
The prevalence of English as a second language does not negate the widespread knowledge of French.
Learning French in school does not guarantee proficiency or everyday usage.
English's dominance in media and business reduces the practical use of French as a second language.

supporting.text: Smaller European nations, such as Iceland or Malta, have their own native languages and minimal French usage.

attacks.text: Smaller European nations, such as Iceland or Malta, have their own native languages and minimal French usage.
French is widely taught in schools across Europe, including in smaller nations like Iceland and Malta.
Many people in smaller European nations learn French as a second language due to its global importance.
Despite being taught, French is not commonly spoken in daily life in Iceland or Malta.
The prevalence of English as a second language overshadows French in many smaller European countries.
French remains an official language of the EU, ensuring its continued relevance in Europe.
English dominance does not negate the fact that French is still spoken by a significant portion of Europeans.
